channel.title: VB .NET sound question:
channel.description:
Please read the whole post before you post, thankyou. ;D
Well, I bet for most programmers, they have seen a keygen or crack that makes sound, but has a small size. I just want to know how they sequence that with such small size, because I don't want to embed mp3's that require API's for a starting sound for my programs, I just want a basic sequencer type of thing that the Keygens and Crackers use, I am not asking for a kegen/crack or warez, but just how to do the sound production.

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:16, topic:81857”]EDIT: Actually, I think I just understood what you mean.

You want to record one note of your sound, and then read a MIDI file to change the pitch at runtime to make the song? Kind of like a sampler?
That’s a clever idea, you’d need to write a decent stretching algo though. www.kvraudio.com development section probably has one.[/quote]

Mopman scores a winner! yes that is what I want, I just didn’t know how to say it right, I’ll check it out.

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

But that’s just my point, you don’t.

If you play a MIDI file on 5 different computers, you’ll most likely get 5 slightly different sounding tracks. Most soundcards adhere to standards such as GM, but that only defines which instruments you’ll find on each channel AFAIK, not what the sound like (it defines them as far as ‘this is a piano’ ‘this is a gunshot’).

Fruityloops dosen’t play midis exactly, it runs them through synths included in it. So I guess the answer to your question would be “write a synthesiser”

EDIT: Actually, I think I just understood what you mean.

You want to record one note of your sound, and then read a MIDI file to change the pitch at runtime to make the song? Kind of like a sampler?
That’s a clever idea, you’d need to write a decent stretching algo though. www.kvraudio.com development section probably has one.

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

I perfectly know what MIDI is as I have my own synthesizer, Midi development sound card, and a little bit more. I just want to know how to make it read the midi sequence and then play the tracks with a specific soundwave just bent or stretched to make the sound like theirs with the different notes, Kind of like how Fruity Loops studio does it.

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

That’s what MIDI does, it’s just instructions that get played through the synthesiser on your card (or if you happen to have your card plugged into something else, through that instead).

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

well, I know it is midi, but it is also going thru its own sequencer of sounds(reminds me of the SNES)

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

On another topic

no point using assembly…

Moron.

[quote=“Bang Train, post:7, topic:81857”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=120286.msg1180436#msg1180436 date=1176974997]
i believe those keygens/crackers are made in assembly.
[/quote]

they use c++ with a some wierd method to include assembly code i 4got it though[/quote]

yeah I think it goes something like …

[C++ code here] __asm { [asm code here] }

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:2, topic:81857”]i believe those keygens/crackers are made in assembly.[/quote]You can use inline asm + c++. Cracks probably use asm to modify files, but doubtful. Keygens don’t need shit.

Read full topic

item.description:

well I just want to know how(with delphi or VB .NET(only .NET, hate VB classic)) to play them, and they sound like it is using its own sound creation code instead from the sound card.

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

They are definitely a MIDI format. (For example, I include all of the original Doom MIDIs with moparscape. 21 songs are 400kb, and zipped they are 111kb)

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

MIDI dosen’t have “a sound” Cheap Synthesisers that come with soundcards do, I guess, so you could be right.

You can use MIDI to create a pretty authentic sounding orchestra, however.

Read full topic

item.title: VB .NET sound question:
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

How can it sound like MIDI? MIDI is not a sound format.

Read full topic
